question: What do you mean he's gone out to lunch? You just said he was still at breakfast!
answer: Come off it, Mr. Dent. You can't lie in front of the bulldozers forever.

question: I'm game. We'll see who rusts first.
answer: This bypass has got to be built and it's going to be built. You should have made your protest months ago.

question: The first I heard of it was when a workman came yesterday. I asked if he'd come to clean the windows, and he said he'd come to demolish the house. He didn't tell me right away of course. First he wiped a couple of windows and charged me twenty quid. Then he told me.
answer: Look. These plans have been on display at the planning office now for a year.

question: On display? I had to go down to a cellar!
answer: That's the display department.

question: I eventually found them in the bottom of a locked filing cabinet in a disused lavatory with a sign on the door saying 'beware of the leopard'.
answer: Mr. Dent, have you any idea how much damage that bulldozer would suffer if I just let it roll straight over you?

question: How much?
answer: None at all.

question: Arthur!
answer: Ford?

question: Arthur! There you are. Here drink and eat with me. We need to talk.
answer: Er, um...now's not the best time, Ford They're going to demolish my home,

question: Whoa. You already know? How? Oh. When you say "they" you mean they. Got it. Listen, I gotta tell you something important, and I gotta tell you now.
answer: But what about my house?

question: C'mon. Let's go to the pub. He said they won't destroy your house until they've finished the beers.
answer: Can we trust him?

question: I'd trust him to the end of the Earth.
answer: And how far's that?

question: Keep the change. You've got ten minutes to spend it.
answer: Three? At lunchtime?

question: Time is an illusion. Lunchtime doubly so.
answer: Very deep. You should send that in to the Reader's Digest. They've got a page for people like you.

question: Drink up.
answer: Why three pints?

question: Muscle relaxant. And eat these. You'll need the salt.
answer: What's going on. Ford?

question: What would you say if I told you I wasn't really from Guilford but from a small planet somewhere in the vicinity of Eetelgeuse?
answer: Why, is it the sort of thing you're likely to say?

question: Remember when we met? That car was racing toward me, I was trying to greet it, you pushed me out of the way? Didn't you find it a little strange that I was trying to shake hands with a car?
answer: I assumed you were drunk.

question: I thought cars were the dominant life form. I was trying to introduce myself.
answer: And that's why you're named after a discontinued car from the seventies?

question: You saved my life that day. Now I'm saving yours.
answer: This must be Thursday. I never could get the hang of Thursdays.

question: Look, if it's about your house...
answer: No, it's not that. It's.... I found her. Ford. The perfect girl. I found her, and then I let her get away. You remember that fancy dress party I told you about?

question: This isn't a long story, is it? We've only got six minutes. Okay. Talk and drink. Fancy dress party.
answer: At that flat in Islington. I told you about it. Last week, remember? I can't bear those sort of parties, didn't want to go, would have much rather stayed home and, I don't know, brush the dog. Anything. But there I was -- and then, there she was...

question: At that flat in Islington. I told you about it. Last week, remember? I can't bear those sort of parties, didn't want to go, would have much rather stayed home and, I don't know, brush the dog. Anything. But there I was -- and then, there she was...
answer: Who are you?

question: I'm Arthur. Arthur Dent.
answer: No, I mean who are you?

question: Oh, the costume. Right. Er, um... Livingston, I presume. Granted. Not as clever as Darwin, but the best I could do on short notice.
answer: You're the first person who's got it right. Everyone keeps calling me Sherlock.

question: Really? I thought the beagle made it rather obvious. Really? I thought the beagle made it rather obvious. She was amazing, Ford. Witty, and beautiful, and brilliant. Four or five degrees. One in math, one in astrophysics, another in biology...
answer: I've got so many degrees I am officially unemployable. Let's drink to that!

question: And just as I was asking myself, "Why is this stunning and intelligent woman even giving me the time of day, out of nowhere she says...
answer: Let's go somewhere.

question: Yeah. It is a bit noisy. There's a lovely little cafe around the corner...
answer: I was thinking Madagascar.

question: Is that a new club on Dean Street?
answer: No. It's a country. Off the coast of Africa.

question: Oh, that Madagascar. Right, off we go then. Good God, you're serious. Well...that's...an extraordinary proposition. But...I can't just up and go. What about my job?
answer: Quit. Get a new one when we return.

question: I can't just...what about my house? Who would feed my dog?
answer: Bring him with.

question: I went to refresh our drinks. When I came back, she was gone. "Would you like to see my spaceship?" Really, what sort of chat up line is that?
answer: More popular than you'd think.

question: I've left messages, sent letters... It's like she's vanished off the face of the earth.
answer: Hey, it happens. Speaking of... We've got two minutes. So drink up.

question: My house!
answer: A round for everyone, on me.

question: A round for everyone, on me.
answer: You really think the world's going to end? Shouldn't we lie down or put a bag over our heads or something?

question: If you want.
answer: Will it help?

question: Not really.
answer: Last orders, then?

question: So you're not from Guilford, which would explain the accent -- which I've always wondered about...and you're not an out of work actor -- but rather a writer for this...this...book thing. I don't feel well. I need a cup of tea.
answer: Here. Eat these. If you've never been through a transmat beam before you've probably lost some salt and protein.

question: If I asked where we were would I regret
answer: We're safe. For now.

question: Good.
answer: We're in a storage hold in one of the ships of the Vogon constructor fleet ...

question: Obviously some strange usage of the word safe I wasn't previously aware of.
answer: Is it?

question: Tell me you're joking.
answer: Okay. I'm joking.

question: And do a reassuring little laugh. Now tell me where we really are.
answer: In the storage hold of a Vogon constructor ship.

question: Get me home. Ford.
answer: Home? Arthur...your home... is...

question: Oh God - it was demolished! I've got to reach my lawyer! He must be back from lunch by now...
answer: You don't remember, do you? Okay. I've got something to tell you. It ain't gonna be easy, but you're gonna have to just deal, okay?

question: Good god. Is this really the interior of a flying saucer?
answer: Yeah. Why?

question: Well, it's a bit squalid isn't it?
answer: Hey man, you're in denial.

question: Blown up? BLOWN UP?! Couldn't you have done something?!!
answer: I did. I saved you.

question: But there's six billion other people.
answer: And all those ants.

question: Yes, but ants aren't exactly people!
answer: And now you're thinking like a Vogon. I saved your life, okay? Which makes us even. Next thing. It's a tough galaxy. You want to survive out here, you really gotta know where your towel is. Now gimme a hand over here. Careful, it's hot. We've got to get off this ship before the Vogons find us. Vogons hate hitchhikers. Which is why they make ships with walls that won't allow the Sub-Etna signal to pass through. So we've got to send the signal up and out if we wanna catch a ride. Pull.

question: What's a Vogon?
answer: Ask the guide. Say "Vogons."

question: That's it? That's all this idiotic book has to say about my home? "Harmless?"
answer: Hey, there are a hundred billion stars in the Galaxy and only a limited amount of space in the book's microprocessors. No one knew much about Earth. That's why I was there. To expand the entry. I fired off a new one to the editor before I got stranded.

question: What does it say now?
answer: Mostly harmless.

question: Ahhh, what the hell is that?!
answer: Here. Put this in your ear.

question: Oh freddled gruntbuggly! Thy suppurations are to me as plerdled gabbleblotchits on a lurgid bee.
answer: Vogon poetry is widely accepted as the third worst in the universe. The second worst is that of the Azgoths of Kria. During a recitation by their Poet Master Grunthos the Flatulent of his poem "Ode to a Small Lump of Green Putty I Found in My Armpit One Midsummer Morning," four of his audience died of internal hemorrhaging, and the President of the Mid- Galactic Arts Nobbling Council survived by gnawing one of his own legs off.

question: Or I shall rend thee In the gobberwarts with my blurglecruncheaon, see if I don't!
answer: The absolute worst poetry was written by Paula Nancy Millstone Jennings of Sussix. It involved decaying swans. Luckily, it was destroyed when the Earth was.

question: And, um, interesting rhythmic devices which seemed to counterpoint the surrealism of the underlying metaphor of the humanity...
answer: Vogonity!

question: ... Vogonity, sorry. Vogonity of the poet's soul, which contrives through the medium of the verse structure to sublimate, er...
answer: ... whatever it was ...

question: ... the poem was about.
answer: Damn.

question: What?
answer: I think you just saved my life again.

question: So this is it? We're going to die?
answer: Yes. No, wait! What's this switch? No, it's nothing. We are going to die.

question: You know, it's at times like this, when I'm trapped in a Vogon airlock with a man from Betelgeuse and about to die of asphyxiation in deep space that I really wish I'd listened to what my mother told me when I was young.
answer: Why? What did you she tell you?

question: I don't know. I didn't listen.
answer: You're sweating.

question: Four to one against and falling...
answer: So, in the name of the people and freedom and, I dunno, democracy and stuff like that, I hereby declare this ship officially stolen!

question: Probability factor of one to one...we have normality, I repeat we have normality. Anything you still can't cope with is therefore your own problem. Please relax. You will be sent for soon.
answer: Hey. Do you mind? I can't hear.

question: Can we put your ego aside for one moment? Something important has happened.
answer: If there's anything more important than my ego on this ship, I want it caught and shot now. Hey...

question: We have a couple of hitchhikers in our receiving bay. I didn't pick them up. The ship did.
answer: Huh?

question: When you engaged the Improbability Drive.
answer: I didn't engage the drive.

question: We picked them up in sector ZZ9 Plural Z Alpha -- where you picked me up.
answer: That's impossible.

question: No. Just very, very improbable.
answer: I don't have time for this! We've got the police of half the Galaxy after us and we stop to pick up hitchhikers?! Okay, so ten out of ten for style, but minus several million for good thinking, eh?

question: Don't. I'll send Marvin. Marvin!
answer: I think you ought to know I'm feeling very depressed.

question: We have something to take your mind off things.
answer: It won't work, I have an exceptionally large mind.

question: I know. Go down to the number two entry bay and bring the two aliens up here.
answer: Just that?

question: Yes.
answer: I won't enjoy it.

question: I've been ordered to take you up to the bridge. Here I am, brain the size of a planet, and they ask me to take you up to the bridge. Call that job satisfaction? - 'cause I don't. "All the doors in this spacecraft have a cheerful and sunny disposition. It is their pleasure to open for you, and their satisfaction to close again with the knowledge of a job well done. Hateful, isn't it? You can thank the Marketing Division of the Sirius Cybernetics Corporation for building robots with GPP.
answer: GPP?

question: "Genuine People Personalities." I'm a personality prototype. You can tell can't you?
answer: Er. . .

question: Sorry, did I say something wrong? Pardon me for breathing, which I never do anyway, so I don't know why I even bother to say it. Oh god, I'm so depressed. And then I've got this terrible pain in all the diodes down my left side. I've asked for them to be replaced but no one ever listens.
answer: Really? Wonder why?

question: I wasn't talking to you.
answer: Zaphod?

question: Ixxie? It is you! IXXIE! Praxibetel Ix, you zarking hoopy! What the hell are you doing here?
answer: I don't know! Just stuck out the thumb and here I am.

question: That is so you.
answer: And look at you! President? Last time I saw you, you were a beach bum.

question: Is it a great galaxy or what? I still can't believe this. Ixxie! Here! ON MY SHIP!
answer: Hey, it's Ford now.

question: Hmm?
answer: My name. It's Ford Prefect. Picked it up on Earth. Sorta grew on me.

question: Okay "Ford" -- you zarking frood.
answer: Oh, this is Arthur. Arthur, this is Zaphod Beeblebrox. My cousin? Semi-half brother?

question: Tricia McMillan?
answer: Arthur?

question: I can't believe this...I've been looking...and you're here? I went to get wine and...
answer: I know. And it was rude to just leave, but I told you I wanted to get away, and he had a spaceship parked outside, well, honestly -- I assumed you were a sort of stay-at-home-and-read-a book type. But you're here...

question: You blew it with her, Earthman, so shut up or I'll kick you in the gones!
answer: There's the Zaphod I remember.

question: You should teach your pal a lesson, Ford. He's a guest on my ship.
answer: I thought you said you stole it.

question: Did they have proper hyperspace authorization? Add that to their list of offences! Blatant disregard for protocol.
answer: You do realize he did what he did because he knew this is what you would do.

question: Rules are rules, Mr. Vice President. And they are made to be followed.
answer: Don't you think this many ships is a bit, oh I don't know -- excessive?

question: The provisions are clear. Under subsection 37a these are the forces we deploy to protect the president in the case of an attempted or actual kidnapping- -- and these are the forces we deploy to apprehend any intentional or actual kidnapper.
answer: You are aware, Commander, that the President kidnapped himself.

question: Hence...
answer: Do you have any idea how ridiculous this is?

question: I suppose I should have said it resembles tea.
answer: So two heads is what does it for a girl, then? I mean, if I'd had two heads. Or three?

question: Or your own space ship.
answer: Anything else he's got two of?

question: Come on, Arthur, don't be like that.
answer: Well, what am I supposed to be like? Green? Bleeping? What?

question: Just be yourself. Have some fun. Does it hurt?
answer: No, I suppose it wouldn't..

question: I mean... I might have an aspirin. Hey. What are they doing in there?
answer: So all that's left is me and you, "mostly harmless," and two lab rats. Look, there's something I should tell you...

question: The Milliard Gargantubrain? A mere abacus, mention it not.
answer: The Omnicognate Neutron Wrangler then?

question: The Omnicognate Neutron Wrangler could argue all four legs off an Arcturan Megadonkey, but only I could persuade it to go for a walk afterwards.
answer: Then what's the problem?

question: Can I help you?
answer: Deep Thought. Do you have...

question: An answer for you? Yes. I have.
answer: There really is an answer?

question: Yes. There really is one.
answer: Oh!

question: Yes. Though I don't think you're going to like it.
answer: Doesn't matter! We must know it!

question: You're really not going to like it.
answer: Tell us!

question: That's it?
answer: That's it.

question: You're looking for the Ultimate Question?
answer: Yep.

question: You.
answer: Me.

question: Why?
answer: No, I tried that. "Why?" "Forty-two." Doesn't work. Let's get her ready, babe.

question: I mean, why do you want to know the Ultimate Question?
answer: Oh. Well -- partly the curiosity, partly a sense of adventure, but mostly I think it's for the fame and the money.

question: Oh. Well -- partly the curiosity, partly a sense of adventure, but mostly I think it's for the fame and the money.
answer: But -- you're President of the Galaxy, aren't you?

question: Yes, Arman.
answer: Arthur.

question: Whatever. Presidential fame is temporary, I find the Question, that's permanent. It sticks. Plus everyone thinks you're deep. Win-win.
answer: But you don't know the name of the computer that other computer was talking about.

question: Which is why I'm going there.
answer: Where?

question: There. To find Deep Thought. On Magrathea.
answer: Magrathea!? Magrathea is a myth, a legend...

question: No, it isn't. It's real, cousin. And this is the only ship in the universe that can get you there.
answer: You mean to tell me you carved up your brain so you could become President so you would get invited to the launching ceremony of this ship...so you could steal it... so you could go to Magrathea -- which, according to most sane people, doesn't even exist?

question: Yep.
answer: Beautiful.

question: Sir, the Heart of Gold has just requested permission to land on Viltvodle 6. Should I pursue?
answer: That is not a request to which I can respond, captain. Should I pursue what? Are you requesting hyperspace clearance so that you may pursue the fugitive?

question: Yes, commander.
answer: Then you must say that, captain -- in request form.

question: Requesting hyperspace clearance to pursue the fugitive, sir.
answer: Thank you. Request acknowledged. Await response. Bring me the request to pursue fugitive forms.

question: Thank you. Request acknowledged. Await response. Bring me the request to pursue fugitive forms.
answer: This is ridiculous! What do you need, an executive order? Fine. I order you. Stop doing this! Go and get him!

question: According to Subsection 94b, paragraph 2, you're not authorized to make such an order.
answer: But I'm acting president!

question: Why does he keep saying that?
answer: I don't know. I'm not used to seeing him this way.

question: You mean fully clothed? Sorry, but I can't for the life of me figure out why you, the most brilliant woman I have ever met, have ended up with that half-witted, self-obsessed, vapid politician! I mean, look at him!
answer: Clearly unlike any guy I've ever met. Look, if you're going to pout your way around space, then maybe you should just go home.

question: I can't. That's the whole point -- and I've been trying to tell you...
answer: Hey, look what I found in the guide. I wouldn't tell her if I were you.

question: She deserves to know.
answer: But if you tell her and she ends up with you because you're literally the last guy on Earth -- you'll always doubt her intentions. Got your towel?

question: Do I need it?
answer: Only always.

question: Send the handkerchief, lord, so that it may wipe us clean. We ask this in your precious holy name... Bless you. CUT TO: Zaphod Beeblebrox, our famous President. The Arkleseizure has exhaled many blessings upon you. What brings you to our humble planet?
answer: I think you know why I'm here.

question: I don't think I do.
answer: Oh, I think you think you don't, but we both know -- you do.

question: The election is ancient history, Zaphod, but if memory serves -- you won, proving that good looks and charm win over brilliance and ability to govern. And incidently -- you are stupid.
answer: That's really not the point.

question: You haven't come halfway across the galaxy to settle a campaign grudge. Why are you here, Zaphod?
answer: I don't know. I was headed for Magrathea, I ended up here.

question: How very, very... ...improbable. I kept a few souvenirs from my former life. Ah, the heady days of space piracy... so young, so foolish.., I'll gladly give you the coordinates to Magrathea... ...provided you bring me something in return.
answer: What?

question: A gun.
answer: A gun?

question: A very special gun. Designed by the greatest computer ever invented, now buried in the bowels of Magrathea.
answer: Fine. I'll get your gun. Just give me the coordinates.

question: And what will you give me to insure your return?
answer: My word as President.

question: Ha! I'd be better off with the dung of a Bethusian Mega Donkey.
answer: Okay, then I'll get you that.

question: We have to go! Let's GO!
answer: Right! Computer! Take us to Magrathea!

question: What? No! Follow those ships!
answer: Hey -- my third arm. I had one, didn't I?

question: Computer?! Isn't there some kind of manual override switch thing?
answer: Yeeessss...

question: WELL WHERE THE HELL IS IT?!
answer: Magic words?

question: Show me the override switch or I'll reprogram you with a very large axe.
answer: I can see this relationship is something we're all going to have to work at.

question: Nothing.
answer: What was it?

question: Nothing. Just my imagination. Alright, stop. Everyone stop and watch me. Something's happening.
answer: Okay. I think we... AH!

question: You, too?
answer: Yes. What was that? I th... What do you think, Zaphod?

question: Name?
answer: Trillian.

question: Not registered.
answer: Try Tricia McMillan.

question: Tricia Yggarstuk McMillanus of Blaard?
answer: No. Tricia Imogene McMillan of Earth.

question: Sorry. No record of "Earth."
answer: Earth. In the Milky Way? {remembering) Um...galactic Sector ZZ9 Plural Z Alpha.

question: Right. Here it is. "Earth. Destroyed." Do you have a second home planet?
answer: Destroyed? No -- that's impossible.

question: Next!
answer: Yes. Hi. We're here about getting a prisoner released?

question: Prisoner release form?
answer: Right. Once I've filled it out can I return to the front of the line, seeing as I've already waited...

question: No. Next!
answer: Can't you do something?! You're President, aren't you?

question: I did?
answer: "Love and kisses, Zaphod?" I saw the form. You didn't even read it, did you?

question: Honey, I'm President of the Galaxy. I don't get a lot of time for reading.
answer: An entire planet, Zaphod. My home. Gone. All because you thought someone wanted your autograph!

question: Trillian...
answer: You knew. Why didn't you tell me?

question: I tried. He threatened me.
answer: Get a backbone, Arthur.

question: No. No! NOOO!!!
answer: I told you this would all end in tears.

question: Life is full of paradoxes, isn't it?
answer: Don't talk to me about life.

question: Here I am, God knows how far from home...
answer: Don't talk to me about God.

question: ...and this is where I see the most spectacular sunset I've ever laid eyes on. We only had the one sun at home. Planet called Earth.
answer: I know. You keep going on about it. It sounds awful.

question: Oh no, it's beautiful. Or at least, it was...
answer: Did it have oceans?

question: Yes. Great wide rolling blue oceans.
answer: Can't bear oceans.

question: So this is how it will all end, then? Me, on a dead planet -- with a manically depressed robot.
answer: You think you've got problems? What are you supposed to do if you are a manically depressed robot? No, don't bother to answer that, I'm fifty thousand times more intelligent than you and even I don't know the answer. It gives me a headache just trying to think down to your level.

question: Aah! Who are you?
answer: My name is not important. You must come with me. Terrible events are afoot. You must come or you'll be late.

question: Late? What for?
answer: What is your name, Earthman?

question: Dent. Arthur Dent.
answer: Late as in "the late Dentarthurdent." It's a sort of threat you see. Never been much good at them myself, but I'm told they can be terribly effective. Your friends are safe. You can trust me.

question: Trust a man who won't tell me his name?
answer: My name? Very well... My name is...Slartibartfast. I said it wasn't important.

question: I told you you might find it a bit disturbing.
answer: I have found this whole day a bit disturbing.

question: Did you know we built planets? Fascinating trade. Doing the coastlines was always my favorite. Used to have endless fun doing all the little fiddly bits round fjords. But the Galactic economy collapsed, and seeing that custom- built planets are something of a luxury commodity... At any rate, there's been a terrible mix up with your planet. You must come with me or it's all going to blow up in our faces. The best laid plans of mice, you know...
answer: ...and men.

question: Mmmm? What?
answer: The best laid plans of mice and men.

question: This is it! Deep Thought...!
answer: Shhh. This is a good bit.

question: Oh great Deep Thought...we have traveled long...and far. Have you calculated... the Ultimate Question? Of Life, the Universe and Everything?
answer: No. I've been watching TV.

question: Oh...
answer: I designed another computer to perform that great task.

question: Oh, right...I forgot. Is it here?
answer: Not here. Another world.

question: It's on another world?
answer: It is another world. Or was.

question: Where?
answer: Ask your companion. Not him.

question: 0kay -- you're sure you don't have the Question? Or a way to you, you know -- access it or something. I think I've done like a lot to get here...
answer: Shhhhhh... The show's back on.

question: Great. This is just great. Let's go find something else for my entire life to be about.
answer: Zaphod. The gun? The one Humma sent us for? We have to get it. You gave the guy your head.

question: I know. Why did I do that?
answer: Um...Deep Thought? We we're told you have a g... Here. Take it. I don't do guns.

question: Thank you. Great! This is a bust, too!
answer: Hey, man, you must be really frustrated. To go through all you did only to come here and get no answer, which means no fame and money, and you deserve that, man. Because you're great -- you're just really, really great.

question: The galaxy was a bit of a shambles, you see. Everyone enjoying themselves being singers and comedians and really creative and interesting things like that. No one doing the boring jobs.
answer: Oh, you had that problem, too?

question: In spades. So a species was genetically engineered to do the boring jobs. Tax inspectors, traffic wardens, government officials. We were commissioned to build a special planet for them. Problem was, some cleverdick made it so any time one of the creatures had an interesting idea it would get a hefty smack around the face.
answer: What? You did that? I've been there!

question: Then I gather you've met some of the inhabitants.
answer: The Vogons?

question: A gun that makes people suddenly see things from your point of view. Useful tool for the deranged evangelist trying to convert the masses, eh? We should get back. Arthur's waiting.
answer: Who cares?

question: I do -- especially since we're both somewhat of an endangered species now.
answer: Why so edgy? Of course you're edgy, your planet's been blown up and you've been tooling around the Galaxy with the guy who signed the order You actually wanted to know the Question because you always thought there was more to life, and now you're crushed because you find out there really isn't. You've got no home, no family, no one to be with -- and you're stuck with me, another in a long line of men who doesn't appreciate you because he's too busy appreciating himself. Give me that thing.

question: Won't affect me. I'm already a woman.
answer: Uh oh -- oh. It's okay, it's only a couple of...

question: Here we are, then. Look familiar?
answer: So -- it wasn't destroyed?

question: Actually, it was. This is a back-up. Earth Mark II.
answer: So you're saying you ... made the Earth?

question: Well, not me alone. It was a group effort. I did my part, though. Ever heard of a place, I think it's called Norway? That was one of mine. Won an award you know. Lovely crinkly edges. I was sorry to hear about it being blown up. Shocking cock up. The mice were furious.
answer: Mice? Who cares about bloody mice?

question: Are you a fan of plate tectonics? Voila! Himalayas. Good, eh? Earthman, you must realize that the planet you lived on was commissioned, paid for, and run by mice. It was destroyed shortly before the completion of the purpose for which it was built. Ten minutes later, we would have been free and clear. But we gave them our standard ten million year warranty and they have come here to retrieve this back-up copy. And they've brought you with them.
answer: They brought...I'm sorry, when you say "mice" do you mean the little white furry creatures with the cheese fixation?

question: These creatures you call "mice" are merely the protrusion into our dimension of hyper- intelligent pan-dimensional beings. The whole business with the cheese must've been a front. They were experimenting on you, you see. A vast computer program...
answer: Ah. I see where you're confused. You see -- we were experimenting on them.

question: Oh, I gather they arranged for you to conduct some primitively staged experiments so they could prod your thinking here and there. But you were actually elements in the computer program. They really are very clever hyper- intelligent pan-dimensional beings. Ah. They've nearly finished the oceans.
answer: So -- you're trying to tell me that mice designed and built Deep Thought...and Deep Thought designed the Earth...which was a giant supercomputer...that you built...to calculate the Ultimate Question. Only, Vogons destroyed it ten minutes before the program was completed?

question: That's bureaucracy for you.
answer: Actually, this explains a lot. All my life I've had this strange feeling that something was going on in the world, something big, something sinister ...

question: That's just perfectly normal paranoia. Everyone in the universe has that. I don't know, perhaps I'm old and tired, but I always think that the chances of finding out what's really going on are so absurdly remote that the only thing to do is say hang the sense of it and keep yourself busy. I'd much rather be happy than right any day.
answer: And are you?

question: No. That's where it all falls down of course. Here we are, then.
answer: Is this...?

question: Ford! Zaphod! TRILLIAN!! What are they-- what's in the food?! WHAT WAS IN THAT TEA!?
answer: Don't worry. You won't feel a thing.

question: Wait a minute, JUST WAIT A SODDING MINUTE!! You want the question that goes with the answer "42" How about "What's six times seven?" Or "How many Vogons does it take to screw in a lightbulb?" Or here's one, "How many roads must a man walk down?"
answer: Hey, that's not bad.

question: Fine. Take it. There's plenty more where that came from because my head is filled, with questions, and I can assure you mate, no answer to any of them has ever brought me one iota of happiness. Confusion? Yes. Indecision? Loads. But happiness...?
answer: We don't want to be happy. We want to be rich.
